Tottenham ; A Poem [by J. A. Heraud

TOTTENHAM; A POEM. CANTO THE FIRST. I Who that upon the hill of snow and blast Seated by Time,âthe tyrant of the browâ Looks on the play-place where his youth was past, The Vale of Mem'ry, and th' eternal glow Of still new Spring;âElysian sweets, and flow Of ever gushing watersâHope and Bliss,â Feels not his torpid bosom's secret throe Kindle with long forgotten extacies? And dreamsâthe hunter's dream were not so blest as his! II The hunter, who in days of old, repos'd On Morven's high heath, in the sun's mild beam, Ere the wild winds and tempest were disclos'd, Rousing him from his calm and summer dream, To the red flashing lightning's lurid gleamâ Lo! he surveys the pine, and blasted oak, Shaking their grey heads, in the leven-stream, To the rude storm-gale and the thunder-stroke, And for the vision sighs whence he had just awokeâ III Spirit of song! so shall thy beam arise, Like morning in thy minstrel's soul, when he Shall turn him to thine early memories, And feel the joy of other times in thee! Then, pleasant to his thought that eve shall be, When, fancy-led, along the western dale, He look'd on the pavillion'd broidery Of the broad sunset, till with its own gale The muse breath'd through his soul, the Hermit's embryo Tale.â IV Then, with that vision of his sunny day, Will the rememb'rance mingle, that as thou Triumph'd in thy creationâthe young ray Of thine Ã¦thereal essence, when thy brow Brighten'd with love upon thy vot'ry's vowâ He, whom the bard would honor, not in vain, Bids him, like his own renovate genius, now Aspire to waken with another strain, The echoes of his lyre, and Toteham's fields again! V Lovely is moonlight to the poet's eye, That in a tide of beauty bathes the skies, Filling the balmy air with purity, Silent and lone, and on the greensward diesâ But when on ye her heavenly slumber lies, Towers of Brus! 'tis more than lovely then.â For such sublime associations rise, That to young fancy's visionary ken, 'Tis like a maniac's dreamâfitful and still again. VI Now brightly pale, and now so wildly dark, As there were witch'ry in her wayward reign, That might upon your time-worn turrets mark The moods of passion, and the spirit's pain, The conflict that toils on through heart and brain, And struggles in the lineamentsâknown too well Withinâas ye may guess who heed the strainâ As though that wand'ring lustre were a spell, Lovely and bright as 'tis, of influence dark and fell! VII What boots it from oblivion to recall, As with the Muse of Amphion, every stone, Shield, bulwark, vantage-coign, and battled wall? Down Time's dark chaos long have they been goneâ And what would they avail the bard alone? The name of Brus!âthat consecrates the spot, Renders its story deathless as his own, And round the Castle shapes of burning thought Hover to hallow itâto be, when that is not! VIII The war in Palestine had ceasedâthat field Of ruthless cruelty, and scorpion strife, Where on the dead and dying armies kneel'd, Before the sepulchre with slaughter rife, And rais'd their stain'd hands to the Lord of Lifeâ Yea, were so madden'd, in religious spasm, They bade the tear drop on the murd'ring knife, From vict'ry's eye, and wild enthusiasm Sang hymns to Him who lay within that holy chasm! IX But that was pastâthey triumph'd and they weptâ And they are goneâand others made as they Their deeds repeated, and in darkness sleptâ 'Till very children armed them for the fray, And rent them from their parent's hearths away, Sweet hecatombs to the grim fiend of war! But he in Palestine had seen his dayâ And ev'ry warrior turn'd him to his star, But Brus to England'sâhereâfrom his own mountains far! X His sire was of the twelve who for the crown Of Caledon, with Edward's wile competed, But scorn'd to hold the right of England's throne, He freely heir'd, and but with freedom greeted.â And here the Earl of Annandale retreated, And saw his son, like the keen eaglet rise, Worthy his monarch fathers, and conceited His Robert was predestined by the skies, To win their long lost seat, and lineal royalties!â XI And is this he, who from the Castle moves Now looking up to heaven, and to the moon, Which there in all her virgin silence roves, And vows a vow that she may hear alone?â Wand'ring the night like herâsave that she shone, But he was darkling, suff'ringâso is she! A cloud hath shorn her gloryâlike his ownâ But, lo! she peers above itâso will he! Toiling and suff'ring, but for Immortality! XII At All Saint's ivied and embattled tow'r, Devote to prayer, and consecrate to praise, He paus'dâbecause the monks at stated hour Were chanting to the Cross their sacred lays, And on his spirit rush'd his happier days, His days of childhood, when he joined the strain, And lov'd upon the gorgeous rite to gaze, As down the choral aisle the priestly train, Paced forth in solemn state, or worshipped at the fane. XIII But now!âsuch thoughts throng'd o'er him, that he wept;â His heart was from its heavenly treasure goneâ And o'er his soul the service stilly creptâ Goneâto the isles of streamy Caledon! And now it came, like a forgotten tone, But to reproach him, who with God had striv'n; And to the Cross round which the moonlight shone, Vesting it like an halo in mid-heav'n, He rais'd his phrensied eye, and pray'd to be forgiv'n! XIV The tear he shed was that of wounded pride, Which for a moment was but thus subdu'd, For soon the passion to the pang allied, Storm'd o'er his soul,âand he, in mightier mood, Sware by his Sires his Saviour, and his God, To assert his own immediate energies, The strength of his own spiritâthrough the flood Of violence and fraud, t' avenge the cries Of his own bleeding land, still echoing to the skies! XV Such of the aspiring is the secret strife, When mighty things are brooding in the breast, And ev'ry function rushes into life, In all their contrarieties confest; And the fierce world within the man comprest In one wild insurrection rises!âSuch Was hisâthe Son of Brusâwho scorn'd the rest That fetter'd him to earth.âBehold him touch His fancy-circled browâhe wakesâit is too much! XVI Glorious conceptionâyet, how full of grief! The dream was dearâbut, oh! the waking wild! A diadem of fire had been relief To the dark truthâhis brow was but beguil'd With a vain semblance, like a fretful childâ And, as a steed by snake from slumber stung, He rush'd through nightâthen turn'd aroundâand smil'dâ Lo! on her hill the Church in moonlight hung, And fainter on his ear the distant vigils rung. XVII Harkâfrom yon ivied and embattled tow'r, With momentary intermitting shriek, The bird of hate profanes this silent hour, Of bitter omens with the moon to speakâ 'Tis hush'd!âagain!âpeace! harsh and dissonant beak!â Up, Nightingale! up to thy light belov'dâ Pour thy full tide of rapture, which we seek To name, or Joy, or Grief, by both approv'd, So thrilling and so wild, with ev'ry passion mov'd! XVIII There is a winding streamlet skirts the hill, That boasts its source from Muswell, and its name; There stood the Brus, and in its mirror still Discern'd another heav'n, and yet the same, With all its azure and its orbs of flameâ Heard the brook's music ever as the breeze Of this calm night in spring tide went and came, And mark'd, amus'd, the regent of the seas Beneath the waters glass'd she sways in their increase. XIX Who doth not know in such a scene of peace, Over such liquid murmurs half reclin'd, How all that is without appears to cease, And the soul mingles with itselfâand mind Forms its own visions variously combin'd, Darkling or brightâpleasing or painful?âHis Rose in one rush of ev'ry shade and kind, A wild confusion of all extacies, Blending and oppositeâhope, terror, sorrow, bliss!â XX Yet he was silent, and had seem'd serene, Had ye observ'd him in that raptur'd hourâ All too intense his visions to be seen In their extern effectâbut like a flow'r, That, while it blossoms sweetest of the bow'r, Conceals and nourishes the cankerâhe Shew not the thought he cherish'd in his core, His heart of heart, though there it revell'd free, Fed on his vital blood, in its own secrecy! XXI Dayspring! lo, the grey east Aurora's blushes Vermeil with beauty; and the spreading sky With one broad glory o'er the horizon flushes, Till the hills lift their gradual heads on high, And all the prospect opens on the eye, Stream, pasture, forest, hamletâone by oneâ Developing its own variety, And all the heav'n is conquer'd by the sun, Dethroning every starâunminish'd and alone! XXII So deep his musings, that he did not mark Nature reviving thus from stated death, Till in the heav'n he heard the herald lark, And on his cheek felt the gale's morning breath Curling his locks, and eke, his mantle wreathe, With its skirts sporting o'er the pleasant Mose, That dimpled with a livelier tide beneathâ And an invisible spirit of fragrance rose From all thingsâand the birds with music chas'd repose! XXIII Tis beautyâharmonyâaround, aboveâ A world of balm at this sweet hour of prime! All beings wooing or returning love, The breezeâthe flow'râthe azure arch sublimeâ And, redolent of songs, the woodland climeâ Precious to fancy, and to minstrel dear, A fruitful theme for many a raptur'd rhime! But yet, the pensive Brus was lonely there, Felt the scene melt his soul, and drop'd the tender tear,â XXIV Then into his own spirit turn'd, and found Nature herself for him had no delight, Till he embrac'd her, where she sat renown'd, In fell and cave, on rock and cloud-capp'd height, And cataractâall majesty and mightâ In his own mountain land of many isles, Proud Caledon!âher monarch in his rightâ âMore glorious on her peaks the morning smiles, âMuch more to be desir'd, and worth a thousand toils!â XXV Thus cried young Brus, and then his arms expanded, As from his heart its strange oppression heaving, And clos'd them on a formâwhose grace demanded Fancy's best powers, in her most high conceiving, Faintly to shadow suchâwithall bereaving Her entire essence from all stain of earthâ It was so heavenly!âyet the Brus was leaving That One, so sweet she seem'd of angel birth, To sink in her own tears, as void and nothing worth! XXVI Oh, there are hoursâand this was suchâwhen Love Comes on the heart, made stern by musings lone, But like the lightning's beauteous flash above A barren waste, dread desolation's throne, To make its perils and its horrors known, Cheerless, and wild:âor like the heav'nly dew That on the blasted heath drops idly down, Or but its dark aridity to shewâ As nothing to that heart its softness may renew! XXVII He turn'd him from that form of purity, Mute, and with fearful gesture; but not so Was she to be discouragedââThis to me? âIt was not thus appear'd thy dawning brow, âWhen first on thee and heaven, around, belowâ âMy raptur'd vision glanced, astonish'd, wild! âThink on yon freezeless fountain, and bid flow âThy bosom as 'twas wontâand be as mild âAs then thou wert!ââand there, she led him like a child. XXVIII âOh, I was darkâand Nature such to me! âThe sun, the moon, the stars were not!âbut you âGaz'd on my rayless beauty piteously, âGuided me to this spring, and o'er me threw âThe hallow'd water's blest and blessing dew, âLaving my eyes, till on their dazzled sight âRush'd the creation, beautiful as new! âBut thou to me wast as a form of light âFor which all things were madeâmore glorious and more bright! XXIX âAnd holy this moss-border'd fount to me, âAnd I have deck'd it with fresh flowerets ever, âAnd holy ever shall its hillock be, âTill thou and Iâbut that can be, oh, never!â âWhom death can not, shall pain or peril sever? âBut ahâwhy dost thou quit thy father's home, âThus in the dead of night, and by yon river âCommune with things so dread, that when I come, âThou start'st as at some foe, or spectre of the gloom?â XXX âBecause 'tis not my Father's home! its wall âIs but a prison to this spiritâhereâ âWhich scarcely brooks its frail and fleshly thrall, âAvailing but the wormâthat banqueter âAlike on prince and peasantâand their peer! âCowards, and weakâignoble, slavish, base! âWhy rise they not like souls resolv'd, and dare? âAnd from their story the deep stains erase, âThat tyranny hath stamp'd on their own dwelling place? XXXI âRise, Sire of Brus! oh, gloriously rise! âAh, would thou mightstâbut thou art old and weak! âIn the vile fetters bound that I despise! âBound in the fetters that I vow to break! âScatter in air!âand on each mountain peak;â âWhereon they deem thy freeborn sons to chain, âWhile the fierce vulture flesh on them his beak,â âDespotic violenceâbut shall deem in vainâ âMy own lov'd landâmy home!âmy crown! and my domain! XXXII Here pause weâand the Wood of Toteham hail, Ere we resume the songâSeated on high, Crown of the hill, an omen to the vale! Fear is the peasant's when he sees the sky Lour o'er thy top with vapour fieryâ Already he beholds the delug'd plain, The corn-field, pasture, in their ruins lie, Which hope had blestâbut, oh! had blest in vain!â This elsewhere have I writ, nor here must write again. XXXIII Vain Wood of the vain Proverb!âwhat art thou? Immortal?âso vain man misdeem'd theeâwhy, The sun, moon, stars shall failâand thou art now, Nought, and a laughterâwhat can Man reply? Poor son of Error!âhe must likewise die!â But not his spirit!âwhy should he repine?â Matter may perishâocean, earth and skyâ But that, the breath of Deity, shall shine Safe in the wreck of worldsâethereal and divine! XXXIV And Spirit e'en in this dim world of strife, Under the stars, oft leaves memorial long, That hath, anew, existence after life, Hallowing some mighty nameâa spotâa songâ Heir of renownâthe praise of heart and tongueâ And so the sons of soul, smit by the levin Of her reflected glory, have forth sprung, Electric!âHappy they to whom is given The Immortality, at once, of earth and heaven CANTO THE SECOND. I Descend, my Muse, from hill and woodland clime! And ponder 'mid the Sisters Seven awhileâ Come! with the spirit of departed time, Talk o'er their tale, and sterner mood beguileâ Who laugh sin not, and sin they who but smile? Then learn, these elms, three hundred years ago, Guerdon'd as many sister's several toil, Of whom one was diminutive, and so The elm she planted grewâirregular and low. II Nay, I have err'd.âOf elms and sisters eight Runs the old tale;âand in the centre stood The eighth young sapling, blossoming, till fate Smote the fair planter, in his ruthless mood, Blighted her beauty, chill'd her vital bloodâ And lo! her kindred and peculiar tree, With wild and strange intelligence endued, Wither'd, and droop'd, and diedâand so did she!â Say, why had not the rest like marvellous sympathy? III And in its place, long stood a walnut-tree, Still bearing leaves, but nor in bulk or height Increasing, and tradition vague and free Tellsâon the spot one who believ'd the light Suffer'd, a martyr, from the world's despiteâ And thence a horror of great darkness fell Full on each blasted branch, a withering blight; And still the ban was on it, like a spell, Memorial and a signâa warning miracle! IV Now, hie thee to the Hermitage, my Muse!â Here with thee hath thy Bard delighted longâ Thou, plastic virgin, who of many hues Weavest the robe of fancy; and the song Makest of many numbers, wildly strung But ever sadâand we have deck'd this cell With the bright rainbow; and these haunts among Waken'd angelic harmony as wellâ But hail, ye banks of Lea!âmy Hermitage, farewell! V Fair is the scene beside the banks of Lea:â And note ye, the broad barge make tardy way Through the bright waves, that, in their majesty, Break into dimples, and laugh in the day: Vocal the deck with mirth and roundelay, Busy all hands, and manifold the freightâ High is thy source, and far thy waters stray, Mingling with streams, dividing shiresâtill late, In the far Thames, O Lee, thou'rt lost, like time in fate! VI Here, as I ween, in other times, De Brus, Infirm and old, on his high-fated Heir, Leant, as on thee their spirits did but muse, River of many waters, deep and clearâ But other thoughts, more stern, and more severe, Caused that mute mood, whose dark intensity Fix'd their unconscious eyes they knew not whereâ But such aye most engages stream or sky, To count the passing clouds,âor spring-wave rippling by. VII Then thus the sire, and rais'd his hoary headâ âSpeak to me, O my son!ânor stand we so, âAs though our spirits commun'd with the deadâ âAll Nature gladnessâwhy should Man be wo? âWhy for the future let the present go? âLook round youâsee the field, the forest, hill; âHeavenâand the waters that beneath us flow, âRejoice in the high sunâexpanding, till âThe infinite breathing world a flood of glory fill! VIII âStill let me look upon itâand on you, âYe pleasant wavesâye glorious skiesâon allâ âAs with a gaze I never may renew!â âConscious of death, yet struggling while I fall, âAs yet enamour'd of this splendid thrall!â âFarewell! a long farewell!âfor in death's gloom, âThis precious moment I can not recallâ âNor see thee more, O Nature, thus in bloom, âBut wreck'd with warring worldsâa ruin, and a tomb!â IX Answer'd the filial virtueââO my sire! âLive and be happy!âtalk not of the grave! âHence! hence! my country! from my heart retire! âLet me be all the sonâalthough a slave, âAn exile from the portion of the brave, âWhich was my fathers'!âOh my father! thou âCom'st on my spirit like the wind and wave, âWaking and kindling ev'ry passion now, âIn all their elements!âand terror's on my brow! X âOh, wild are all the pulses of my breast! âFather, thou tremblestâand thy touch is chill!â âYet, cheer theeâall will yet be wellâand rest âRestore thee.ââ âI am faint, my son, and ill!â âBut be it, heaven, according to thy will!â âMy long and earthly pilgrimage is doneâ âThere is a voice that warns meââLingering still? ââThy fathers wait for thee, and claim their son!â âBehold meâlo! I come!ââhe pausedâand is he gone?â XI Noâhe but swoons from faintnessâ'tis a trance Serene and heav'nly!âo'er him stood his Heir, Anxious for aidâwhen lo! he saw advance A musing Monkâhe hail'd himâhe is there, Breathing the balm of solace to despairâ âI worship at the Altar of St. Loyâ âAnd need not tell thee of his waters rare, âNor of their many miracles of joy; âThou know'st them wellâthen well do we the boon employ!â XII âLoâhe revives!âmy Lord of Annandale, âGive thanks to God and to his saint!âand lean âOn our good arms, to breathe the fresh'ning galeâ âSt. Loy will aid thee!ââquoth the sire, âAmen.â Nor moreâbut suffer'd them to bear him then, Trembling from weakness, but absorb'd in thoughtâ Nor heard the Monk as he with words again, To cheer their slow and mournful progress soughtâ âHigh praise to Loy is due, and well on earth on wrought!â XIII âLong slept he in obscurity's dim vale, âTill Clothaire found his worth and bade him shine, âAnd then the air of Courts he did inhale, âAnd minister devoutly at the shrine, âThat he, no less than heav'n, had made divine; âAnd now his soul is sainted where he reigns, âWorship'd by earthâand I, O Loy, am thine!â âAnd much from thee the Ham of Totten gains, âThine Altar and thy Well the glory of her plains!â XIV Faint are the steps of age, and sick the heartâ Here rest ye him awhile, before the Cross, Whose lofty column, edified with art, Looks o'er the field, and the surrounding fossâ There did De Brus recline him on the moss, While the good monk, with words of gentle cheer, Sought to relieve himâbut his words were lossâ Their import met not his abstracted ear, And other thoughts employ'd his highly-fated Heir! XV ââAnd do ye not remember the long train âOf mourners, tending on their shrouded queen? âHere did they rest, and thence this spot obtain âHonor and yon memorial!â âFrom the green Upsprung the younger Brus with wilder mienâ âMemorial of his fate!âIt was the time âWhen he the twelve competitors between âJourney'd, a judge, to visit Celtic clime, And on her innocent head heav'n 'veng'd his secret crime!â XVI âRoyal memorial! monument of death, ââBuilt to himselfâ, like Egypt's king of old âHis âdesolate place,â where might repose beneath âThe pompous pyramid his crumbling mold!â âThou speak'st not to a heart to freedom coldâ âThe oppressor hath no charm to cheat the grave! âHis dearest in the common tale is toldâ âAnd he must mingle with the meanest slave! âHe is but mortal man!âHope animates the brave! XVII âAnd were he demonâI could exorcise âNobler and mightier spirits from the tomb, âAttended with the vengeance of the skies,â âTheir own,âtheir country's;âand the tyrant's doom! âOft I behold them in the wrathful gloom, âEach on his cloud, or in his tempest tost, âLike many meteors or the lightning's bloom, âMingled of mist and moonlightâlov'd but lost! âWallace, and Falkirk's fieldâa visionary host!â XVIII St. Loy! here is thy fountainâEmblem pure Of chaste unostentatious charity,â Never in vain intreated, ever sure; Yet o'er the marge thy waters fair and free Ascend not, overflowing vauntingly, But in thy bounty humble as unfailing! In grief, disease and sickness visit thee, But part in joy, changed by thy holy healing To manhood, strength and life, thy far renown revealing! XIX There is thy Offertory, and thy shrine, Simple, inartificial; nor of fame, Nor any honor save that it is thine, And all its glory centres in thy name!â Now with the Monk before that altar-frame, Kneels either Brus, and now the suffering sire Waked to his son, and o'er his spirit came A moment's renovation, to expire,â He press'd his Robert's hand, and blest him:ââBeam of fire! XX âI see thee struggling to reveal thy soul, âRedeem thy country, and restore her fame, âAnd free her children from the vile control, âThat curb'd their spirit, and abas'd my name,â âYea, warp'd my judgment to the tyrant's claim, âTill, like the Genius of his country's cries, âFrom Carron's banks, the voice of Wallace came, âAnd, like a glory bursting from the skies, âHe pierced the veil of prejudice, and kindled on her eyes! XXI âThen seem'd I one suspended o'er a chasm, âSo awful deep, that it the heart dismay'd, âHarrowing the spirit with one convulsive spasm! âThe heaven's own glittering canopy o'erhead, âAzure, sereneâbut in its beauty dreadâ âThe thunder-cloud beneathâstill sending out âLightnings, with more than earthly blue and red, âBut to display the yawning gulph, without âCentre or hope, and leave the soul in darker doubt!â XXII Thus spake the Father, but the Son is muteâ Too many feelings are in force for speech, And for the sway and mastery disputeâ Grief for his sireâand triumph nought may reach, And nothing but the love of peril teach, That joys above the abyss of gloom and fear, To take its stand, so, o'er the flashing breach, He may on th' utter heaven's unclouded sphere, In all its glory, gazeâand mingle with it there!â XXIII Thus, kneeling at the shrine, as in a swell, A tide of thought suffused, he seem'd to pray, While extacy most inexpressible, Wing'd from this scene of things his soul away, Charm'd by mysterious hymns that o'er his clay Seem'd in melodious silence to descendâ And on his mental eye another day Arose, with visions manifold to blend Forms of all shades and hues, that mingle and contend. XXIV And there, wrought on the Ã¦ther deep and blue, Did spirits tournay in the strife of spears; And buckler, brand and helm he seems to view, And their apparent conflict feebly hearsâ Now feels himself among themânobly dares Above the mightiest in the loud alarm, And like the angel of the gale appears, To ride the whirlwind, and control the storm! But lo, again 'tis gloomâand other visions formâ XXV Behold! another vision!âthe white cliff Over the ocean beetles awfully, And there the prostrate lion stark and stiff Groans to the loud winds and the roaring sea, The heav'ns are dark and thunder their decree!â O'er other rocks gigantic, wild and rude, The northern eagle rises fair and free, Her wings expanding o'er her mighty brood,â Claps them in upper heav'n, and drinks the golden flood. XXVI Now walks a Goddess o'er the mountain-land, Bloom on her cheek; and freshness in her lips, Scattering the valley's treasures from her hand;â Light-heralds her, dispelling the eclipse That reign'd before, and o'er the lofty ships In darkness sets, where the broad-rounded sun In the pavilion of the ocean dipsâ And lo! behind her, and about her, run Glory's far length'ning beams,âand Freedom's work is done! XXVII Then struggling cloud and sun-beams he beheld Arise o'er heaven, and from their wild collision, Storms went abroadâbut neither yet prevail'dâ When list! a still small voice, sweet and Elysian, Whispering the abstracted ear, dispell'd the visionâ âNo further we futurity unfoldâ âEnoughâwe cherish Hope but not ambitionâ âLook on thy SireââHe turn'd him, and behold! In the Monk's arms he layâpale, breathless, pulseless, cold! XXVIII Such were the honors of thine ancient dayâ Would that a Zeuxis had pourtray'd thy charms! But since an humbler hand hath made assay, The shade that chastens, and the light that warms, Blending in the sweet strife which ne'er alarms, O Tottenham, the fair! indulgent smile! XXIX Wed to the noble and the consecrateâ Tenure of kings, of princes, and of peersâ Valley of recollections passing sweet,â The play-place of the poet's tender yearsâ But more than allâthis, this the spot endears, Field of renown, wherein the royal Brus, Endur'd the conflict of first hopes and fears That in the free-born heart and mind effuse The elective seeds, but seen by heaven and by the Muse!
